bestBHT.bht: Paul, displaying modesty, contrasts his previous prediction of likely loss of life with his new proclamation: there will be no loss of life, only of the ship. This brings hope to those who had given up. By declaring, Whose I am, and whom I serve, Paul reinforces his unwavering faith and devotion to God. This profound statement reveals his trust in God's protection. Despite the imminent shipwreck, the assurance of no loss of life would undoubtedly comfort the entire company.

Albert Barnes: There shall be no loss - This must have been cheering news to those who had given up all for lost.
As Patti had manifested great wisdom in his former advice to them, they might be now more disposed to listen to him.
The reason why he believed they would be safe, he immediately states.
Philip Schaff: No loss of any man’s life among you, but of the ship.
Whose I am, and whom I serve.
One of the noblest utterances that ever came from the lips of man.
Archibald T. Robertson: Paul shows modesty (Bengel) in the mild contrast.
No loss of life (αποβολη ψυχης ουδεμια).
He had foretold such loss of life as likely (verse Acts 27:10), but he now gives his reason for his changed view.
John Gill: To take heart and courage, and not be cast down, though things had been thus with them."
There will be a shipwreck, and so every man's life will be in danger, and yet not one will perish.
if they could but believe it, must be good news to all the company.

bhtAttempts.bht: Paul, displaying modesty and a changed view, declares that there will be no loss of life, only of the ship. This news brings hope to those who had previously given up. Having proven his wisdom, Paul's words may hold greater weight. By proclaiming, Whose I am, and whom I serve, Paul affirms his faith in God and reminds everyone of his steadfast devotion. This profound statement emphasizes the trust Paul has in God's protection. Despite the imminent danger of a shipwreck, the assurance of no loss of life must be a comforting and uplifting message to all who hear it.

Paul exhibits modesty as he contrasts his previous prediction of a likely loss of life with his current declaration that there will be no loss of life, only the ship. This news renews hope for those who had given up. With his wisdom recognized, Paul's words carry more weight. By proclaiming, Whose I am, and whom I serve, Paul affirms his deep faith and unwavering devotion to God. This profound statement underscores his confidence in God's protection. Despite the imminent shipwreck, the assurance of no loss of life must be a source of comfort and encouragement for all.
